summaries.body: With nearly 600,000 car owners in the United States stuck in limbo, Volkswagen missed a court deadline to present a plan to bring its cars into line with clean air rules. A judge gave the company an extension until April 21.

display_asset.caption: Johan Cruyff playing against Argentina in the 1974 World Cup.

summaries.body: Johan Cruyff, the Netherlands' greatest soccer star, whose brash style helped revolutionize the way the game is played, died on Thursday. He was 68.

display_asset.caption: Beyonce with Jay Z, second from right, who announced his plans for the Tidal streaming music service in March 2015 in Manhattan.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: Revenue from music sales in the U.S. has hovered around $7 billion since 2010, but there have been drastic shifts in listener behavior as streaming services have supplanted CDs and downloads.

display_asset.caption: Sujit Choudhry, who stepped down this month as dean of the law school, remains on the Berkeley faculty. Ms. Sorrell filed a civil suit saying the punishment meted out against him was inadequate.
display_asset.credit: University of California, Berkeley, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A spate of high-profile cases of sexual harassment at the University of California, Berkeley, has tarnished the school's image as a center of social activism.

display_asset.caption: North Carolina lawmakers gathered on the House floor for a special session on Wednesday.

summaries.body: North Carolina legislators passed a bill barring transgender people from bathrooms and locker rooms that do not match the gender on their birth certificates.

display_asset.caption: “I’ve been having bad dreams about her being burned up,” said Donald Little, whose mother was mistakenly cremated.

summaries.body: After a Times article about a funeral home mix-up in which a family eulogized the wrong woman, the son of the woman who was mistakenly cremated has come forward.

display_asset.caption: The idea of replacing New Zealand’s flag has percolated for decades, with new proposals for changing it cropping up every few years.

summaries.body: New Zealand spent two years thinking about a replacement, and judges considered 10,292 options, but in the end the country chose to keep the century-old design of its flag.

display_asset.caption: The president took to the dance floor at a state dinner in Argentina.
display_asset.title: Obama Dances the Tango

summaries.body: At the end of a state dinner with President Mauricio Macri of Argentina, President Obama danced the tango.
The word “O.K.” has now been around for 177 years. It first appeared in The Boston Morning Post on March 23, 1839, to mean “all correct.”

display_asset.caption: Notre Dame’s Matt Farrell, right, said players on his team often competed for one another’s extra tickets.

summaries.body: Bribing teammates with candy? Many N.C.A.A. basketball players turn to bartering — or other methods — to procure tournament tickets for family and friends.
Red numbers are piling up for William A. Ackman. Losses at the pharmaceutical company Valeant have pushed Mr. Ackman's hedge fund down 25 percent for the year.

display_asset.caption: Enrichetta Ravina, an assistant professor of finance, has filed a gender discrimination lawsuit against Columbia University.
display_asset.credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

summaries.body: A Columbia University professor has filed a sexual harassment suit. Enrichetta Ravina said officials belittled her complaints that a colleague made repeated advances.
For the Cuba state dinner, Michelle Obama chose to wear a dress by the Indian-American designer Naeem Khan. Mrs. Obama has often worn his pieces.

display_asset.caption: Alex Rodriguez will turn 41 in July and now says the end is in sight.
display_asset.credit: Jerome Miron/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

summaries.body: The Yankees star Alex Rodriguez says he will retire after the 2017 season. The move, which he announced to ESPN, would come at the end of his current deal.

display_asset.caption: A man in a sequoia tree in downtown Seattle on Tuesday. He has rebuffed the authorities’ attempts to negotiate.

summaries.body: An agitated man climbed an 80-foot sequoia tree in downtown Seattle and defied efforts to bring him down for more than 24 hours before finally descending unharmed Wednesday.

display_asset.caption: The mountain lion known as P-22 who lives in Griffith Park in Los Angeles.

summaries.body: The prime suspect in a koala's death at the Los Angeles Zoo is a mountain lion named P-22. It appears to have motive, opportunity and the means to climb a 9-foot fence.

display_asset.caption: Jackson Hole, a community in Hebei Province, on the outskirts of Beijing, mimics the aesthetics of Jackson Hole valley in Wyoming.
display_asset.credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times

summaries.body: There is a Vancouver Forest in Beijing and a Thames Town in Shanghai. But China is now calling for an end to “foreign” and “bizarre” names for housing developments.

display_asset.caption: Riders in Los Angeles board a Megabus for San Francisco. The company’s terms and conditions limit its liability for baggage to $250.
display_asset.credit: Richard Hartog/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images

summaries.body: A few weeks after a Megabus caught fire, many of the passengers have encountered a lack of recourse to collect compensation on thousands of dollars in lost property.

display_asset.caption: Billy Joel, performing at Madison Square Garden in December 2014.

summaries.body: Billy Joel’s “Piano Man” and John Coltrane’s “A Love Supreme” are part of a diverse crop of new inductees to the Library of Congress’s National Recording Registry.
The colors of Belgium’s black, yellow and red flag were reflected on famous landmarks, including the Eiffel Tower, around the world on Tuesday in a show of solidarity.
In Fresno, Calif., a mirrored headboard caught the sun in just the right way (or perhaps just the wrong way), and burned a family’s carport to a crisp.

display_asset.caption: Kevin Hart at the Academy Awards.

summaries.body: The comedian Kevin Hart will publish a memoir that explores his early troubles. “My kids know I’m a big deal," he said, adding, “Now I’ll have a book out to prove it.”

posts.footer: — Nick Denton, the founder of Gawker. The online news organization has been ordered to pay more than $140 million in damages for invading the privacy of the wrestler Hulk Hogan. Gawker

display_asset.credit: Eve Edelheit/Tampa Bay Times, via AP

summaries.body: We now know that the trial was a sham from the start.

display_asset.caption: Mark Davis, the Raiders’ owner, in 2014. “There’s nothing we can do,” Davis said Tuesday of talks with the city of Oakland about a new stadium. “We are in a holding pattern.”

summaries.body: Despite the criticism the N.F.L. has received over gambling and daily fantasy sports, the Oakland Raiders' owner says he is still looking for ways to move the team to Las Vegas.

display_asset.caption: David Chang’s next place will deliver food in the style of his Momofuku restaurants.

summaries.body: The next restaurant by David Chang, the chef behind Momofuku, will be delivery only. “It’s sort of my dream restaurant,” he said of a space that diners can't complain about.

display_asset.caption: Lauren Bacall in “To Have and Have Not.” A class-action complaint is seeking to prevent films with tobacco imagery from receiving G, PG or PG-13 ratings.

summaries.body: A class-action complaint seeking to prevent films with tobacco imagery from receiving anything but R ratings was assigned to a federal judge on Monday.

display_asset.caption: A group is led through an introductory course of meditation techniques at The Kitchen in Brooklyn.
display_asset.credit: Brian Harkin for The New York Times

summaries.body: Mind-based therapies may ease lower back pain with a combination of meditation, body awareness and yoga, a new study found.

display_asset.caption: The remains of the Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, after it was hit by an American airstrike in October.

summaries.body: The new U.S. commander in Afghanistan apologized for the bombing of a Doctors Without Borders hospital in the northern city of Kunduz last October.

display_asset.caption: Gov. Nathan Deal, who has expressed doubts about proposals that might appear to tolerate discrimination, has until May 3 to reach a decision on what lawmakers named the Free Exercise Protection Act.

summaries.body: Companies and sports organizations could have an effect on the debate over a Georgia bill that would strengthen legal protections for opponents of same-sex marriage.

display_asset.caption: Taxis blocking a road in Jakarta, Indonesia, as public transportation drivers on Tuesday protested against ride-hailing apps.

summaries.body: The city center of Jakarta, Indonesia, was paralyzed Tuesday by a violent mass protest by taxi and other public transportation drivers against ride-hailing apps.
